Le-co

Minimalistic-ish modular UI library

git repo

Instalation

However ever you like: use compiled css with all possible modules from dist folder, call trough npm, fork/clone or include into your scss.

For grids and other responsive patters you can specify set of breakpoints they will be generated against. 

$breakpoints: (
    "": "481px",
    "l": "767px"
);

Setting above will produce grid structure with classes like c-f1 that will kick in at 481px of width and c-l-f1 be effective at 767px and up.

Modifiers

Completely hiding element:

.hidden

Hiding text of the element:

.text-access

Float left:

.f-left

Float right:

.f-right

Ensuring image will keep proportions

.r-image

Mixins

Common clearfix:

@mixin clearfix

Removing text from node:

@mixin text-access

Box sizing set:

@mixin border-box

Sprite mixin:

@mixin icon-sprite($is-bposition: 0 0, $icon-sprite:'pc.png')

Universal on mouser over fade in:

@mixin trans-fade($topacity:0.8, $ttime: .3s)

Universal on change configurable transition:

@mixin transition($tattribute: all, $ttime: .3s, $tdelay: .3s)

Crossbrowser one-parameter border radius:

@mixin bradius-s($radius-s:10px)

Crossbrowser multiparameter border radius:

@mixin bradius-c($radius-t: 10px,$radius-r: 10px,$radius-b: 10px,$radius-l: 10px)

Crossbrowser top-down css gradient:

@mixin td-gradient($td-g-color1: #ffffff, $td-g-color2: #bbbbbb)

Crossbrowser left-right css gradient:

@mixin lr-gradient($lr-g-color1: #ffffff, $lr-g-color2: #bbbbbb)

Crossbrowser transform (multiple values have to be in parentheses e.g. (2px,2px) ): 

@mixin transform($ttype, $value)

Inprint effect mixin:

@mixin fx-inprint

Inprint effect mixin helper - removes vertical jump caused by suddenly added border width: 

@mixin fx-inprint-helper

CSS triangles/labels mixin:

@mixin triangle($size:5px, $direction:left, $inverted:false, $color:#000)

Modules

Navigation module:

.nav(.horizontal) > .nav--list > .nav--item > .nav--link

Media module (NOT FINISHED):

.media > .media--content

Solutions

CSS navigation

Content wrapper:

.content-cell#[id]

Content call:

href="#[id]"

Grid systems

Lemony provide three grid systems. Base grid offers common grid functionality where a cell occupies as many collumns as specified within class name (e.g. .c-2 cell spans trough two collumns). Fractional grid on the other hand uses number in class as a spectification of occupied portion of the whole available with of parent container ( e.g. .c-f2 occupies one half of the row). Third system is block grid , which transforms any ordered or unordered list into a grid-like view (e.g. .bgrid-large-6 will display up to 6 items in a row).

Grid usage

Sass variable to set number of collumns in grid (default is 12): 

$grid-cell

Sass variable to set number of collumns in block grid (default is 12): 

$block-grid-cell

Main grid container (can be used as "row" practically anywhere): 

.container

Setting fixed size on container - centered:

(.container).fixed

Setting full size on container - centered:

(.container).full

Column container - simple grid row:

(.container).full

Adding small (1%), medium (2%) or lartbe (5%) left and right padding (text gutter for grid): 

(.container).tg-small/medium/large

Grid container defining mobile wrappers, that should have a gap and not cover whole screen - usually one parent wrapper: 

.row

Grid structure:

(.container) > .row > .c-1/.c-f1

OR

.container > .c-1/.c-f1

Block grid:

(.container) > (ul/ol).bgrid-large-6

Block grids have three variations that can be used together to alter responsive behaviour. Following example displays up to 6 items on desktop, 4 on tablet screen and 2 on smallest screens:

.container > (ul/ol).bgrid-large-6.bgrid-medium-4.bgrid-small-2

Flex grid in row:

.flex-row > .flex-cell

Flex grid in row reversed:

(.flex-row).reverse > .flex-cell

Flex grid in column:

(.flex-row).column > .flex-cell

Flex grid in column reversed:

(.flex-row).column-reverse > .flex-cell

Dominant flex cell will go 100% wide in medium screen:

(.flex-cell).dominant

First flex cell will go to the first place on small screen:

(.flex-cell).first

Text elements

I have reset the sensors to scan for frequencies outside the usual range. By emitting harmonic vibrations to shatter the lattices. We will monitor and adjust the frequency of the resonators. He has this ability of instantly interpreting and extrapolating any verbal communication he hears. It may be due to the envelope over the structure, causing hydrogen-carbon helix patterns throughout. I'm comparing the molecular integrity of that bubble against our phasers.

Headings

Note: Heading below use p>strong. You should use heading tags.

.peta .heading

.tera .heading

.giga .heading

.mega .heading

.kilo .heading

.heading (default)

.micro .heading

.nano .heading

.piko .heading

  • USS Enterprise - NCC-1701 - Commanded by Robert April (2245–2250) , Christopher Pike (2250–2265), James T. Kirk (2265-2270, 2271–2285), and Willard Decker (2270-2271), Vessel's self-destruction carried out while in orbit of the Genesis Planet, to prevent ship from falling into Klingon hands.
  • USS Reliant - NCC-1864 - Ship on which Pavel Chekov serves as first officer. Assigned to Project Genesis and later hijacked by Khan Noonien Singh. Destroyed by Genesis Device detonation.
  • USS Excalibur - NCC-26517 - Part of the tachyon blockade during the Klingon Civil War. Later commanded by Captain Mackenzie Calhoun in Star Trek: New Frontier.
  • USS Shenandoah - NCC-73024 - Taken by Dax and Worf to rescue a Cardassian informant from the Dominion. Severely damaged by the Jem'Hadar en route to deliver diplomatic message to Grand Nagus Zek.
  • USS Stargazer - NCC-2893 - Jean-Luc Picard's first command. Abandoned following the Battle of Maxia, later returned to Starfleet.

Library is free for non-comercial and commercial use but cannot be re-sold as a standalone product.
